title: What makes us laugh?
intro: Some people are funny whatever they do. Others... well, when they try to make us laugh all they do is embarrass themselves. Alice and Neil discuss humour and teach you related vocabulary. Neil is a bit of a comedian but will he manage to make Alice laugh?
this_week_question: Which Greek word means the study of laughter and its effects on the body? Is it…

vocab.desc: a type of comedy where a comedian performs in front of and talks directly to their audience
being too interested in yourself – for example your appearance or other personal qualities
wanting to be successful in your chosen career
to keep on trying to achieve something even when it’s difficult
people who are generally quiet and more interested in their own thoughts and feelings than in spending time with other people
people who are generally lively, outgoing, and enjoy the company of others

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Alice…

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: … and I'm Neil. OK Alice, I've got something for you here… a question…

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Ready? What is the Mexican version of One Direction?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Um… No idea.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Juan Direction. Get it?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Very good…

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Juan Direction... You know?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Yes, yes, I get it.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Never mind. Can you guess what the subject of today's show is instead?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Is it bad jokes?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Come on! That was a good little gag! Yes. The subject of today's show is… what makes us laugh. And in this context, to get something, for example a gag – or joke, means to understand it. We all like to laugh – well not you apparently – but most of us do! It's good for our health, it reduces stress and releases feel-good hormones in the body.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: OK, thank you, Neil. But how about answering today's quiz question? Which Greek word means the study of laughter and its effects on the body? Is it… a) risology? b) gelotology? or c) comology?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: That's difficult and I'm going to say c) comology because it's got the word 'comedy' in it, you see?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Oh, very good. OK. Well, we'll find out later if you're right. Now, did you know, we rarely laugh when we're on our own? Laughter is a social thing that we generally like to share with other people.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Really? I laugh when I'm watching cartoons on my own – don't you, Alice?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: No, Neil, I don't. Anyway, some researchers believe that the purpose of laughter is related to the way we bond with each other. And the more we laugh, the more we bond as a group.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Interesting idea. It could explain why stand-up comedy – where a comedian performs in front of and talks directly to their audience – is very popular entertainment. But what does it take to keep your audience laughing? Let’s listen to Steve Byrne, a successful US comedian talking about this.

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Steve Byrne, comedian The one single thing an aspiring comedian should do is to write, write, write and talk about the things that make them laugh. Selfishness – time to be selfish – time to be a little narcissistic. What is it that makes you laugh? Because that will get you closer to finding your voice. Because ultimately that's why people come see you.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So comedians need to be selfish and narcissistic – that sounds pretty negative!

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Yes, it does. Narcissistic means being too interested in yourself – for example your appearance or other personal qualities. And aspiring means wanting to be successful in your chosen career.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And what does Steve mean when he says comedians need to find their voice?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Well, he means they need to talk about what they think in a way that's unique – meaning unusual or special – to them.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: OK. Let's listen to Steve again talking about turning 40 and what he finds funny about that.

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Steve Byrne, comedian When you turn 40 you will hear this in your life and hopefully you'll hear this the rest of your life. 'You look good for 40. You look good for 52. You look great for 63.' You never hear that when you're young. You never hear: 'You look good for 19.' You think there's going to be some magic potion – some magic shortcut to it all. It's writing and getting up on stage. It takes a lot of perseverance and it's such a competitive occupation. You know, you've just got to outwork everybody.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, we heard Steve making his audience laugh there. And by the way, Alice, you look fantastic for 40.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: That's not funny, Neil. I'm only 39 and you know it. Anyway, moving on, Steve says there's no magic potion or shortcut to success. You have to work hard – it doesn't happen by itself. And perseverance means to keep on trying to achieve something even when it's difficult.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: He says you have to outwork everybody – which means to work harder than everybody else. Steve certainly doesn't make comedy sound much fun, does he?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: No. In fact some people say there's a connection between depression and comedy – that comedians can be introverted and depressive.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Is that right? Introverts are generally quiet people who are more interested in their own thoughts and feelings than in spending time with other people.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Yes, you'd think that most comedians would be extroverts – people who are lively and enjoy the company of others. OK I think it's time for the answer to our quiz question, Neil. I asked: Which Greek word means the study of laughter and its effects on the body? Is it… a) risology? b) gelotology? or c) comology?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yes. I said c) comology, which I think I'm beginning to regret now.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Yes, well, indeed. Sorry, I'm afraid that's the wrong answer. It's actually b) gelotology – which comes from the Greek word, gelos, meaning laughter.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: OK. You can stop sniggering now, Alice and just tell us today's words once again?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Alright then. Here they are: get something (e.g. a joke) gag stand-up comedy narcissistic aspiring unique perseverance outwork introverts extroverts

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, that just about brings us to the end of today's 6 Minute English.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: See you next time.

transcript.author: Both
transcript.text: Bye.
